questions.content: A professional has duties to their employer, clients, the profession, and the public. They also have a "duty to themselves." Which of the following actions falls outside the acceptable scope of this "duty to themselves"?
questions.hint: Recall the hierarchy of a professional's duties. Which duty is considered paramount, and how does the "duty to oneself" fit within that framework?

options.text: Insisting on all rights under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Insisting on a satisfactory work environment
Insisting that their own best interest is a priority

Insisting on adequate payment from a client or employer.
Hint: Recall the hierarchy of a professional's duties. Which duty is considered paramount, and how does the "duty to oneself" fit within that framework?
Answer Key & Details:
•	Correct Answer: C
•	Rationale: A professional's paramount duty is to the public welfare. While professionals have a duty to themselves (e.g., ensuring a safe workplace, fair compensation, and basic rights), this duty does not override their duties to the public, employer, or client. Insisting that their own best interest is the top priority would violate this established hierarchy of duties.
•	Difficulty: 3 (DIFFICULT)
•	NPPE Syllabus Area: I.2
•	Source Reference: Ethics, 6th ed., p. 219-220
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

•	Rationale: OHS legislation defines the role of a "prime contractor" who is responsible for the health and safety of all employees and the public on a worksite with multiple employers. questions.content: The Bre-X mining fraud of 1997, where core samples were falsified, led the Canadian Securities Administrators (CSA) to issue National Instrument 43-101. What does this instrument regulate?
